question: What are some Paris traveling tips and good places to visit?

answers.html:
Do:

  • Always say "bon jour" (or "bon soir") and au revoir when entering and exiting a retail establishment (restaurants, stores, etc.) (respectively) Americans typically don't do this, but it's considered a bit rude in Paris.
  • Make at least a token effort to speak French. Even if you suck at it (as I do.)
  • Pack comfortable walking shoes -- and USE THEM. Walking and wandering is the best thing to do in Paris. Even natives do it all the time.
  • Stop in plenty of bakeries to enjoy the brioches, croissants, and pastries. Do this often. I don't care if you're on a no-carb diet, screw the diet while you're in Paris.
  • If you plan to visit any museums at all (and why wouldn't you??) definitely plan ahead -- get the Paris Museum Pass beforehand to avoid the long, long ticket lines at the actual museum. There are a number of places you can do this, or (I believe) you can go online.
  • Spend at least a few hours just sitting outside at a cafe, sipping coffee, nibbling on a pastry and watching the world go by.
  • Keep in mind that Paris is a major, world city. The same safety precautions you need to take in New York City or Chicago or London or Shanghai or Madrid, you also need to take in Paris: be aware of your surroundings, keep your wallet in your front pocket, be on guard when a stranger is within arm's reach, etc. The same manners are also required: don't just stop in the middle of the sidewalk and expect people not to shove you or curse at you, don't meander around, don't walk in a large group that takes up the entire sidewalk, etc.

Don't:

  • Refer to a waiter as "Garcon." (He is simply "Monsieur," and if you must get his attention, acceptable phrases to use are "S'il vous plait" or "Excusez-moi.")
  • Wait for the waiter to bring you the check. Lingering after the meal is much more acceptable and common in Paris than it is in the U.S., so if you want the check, you must ask for it.
  • Suggest to a French waiter that "all wines are the same." (I heard this done once.) The poor waiter nearly burst a blood vessel in restraining himself from punching them in the nose.
  • Insult people or establishments in English, assuming the locals don't understand you. They probably do.
  • Wear a baseball cap or sweats, unless you are at a gym or playing a sport. (Not just in Paris, but EVER.)
  • Wear a fannie pack or old-person jeans (mom jeans, etc.), EVER,

answers.html:
I am surprised that nobody has mentioned about Paris’s arrondissments (divisions).

Paris is divided into 20 arrondissments. They’re arranged clockwise like a snail shell from the city center.

So, which is the best one to stay?

A lot depends on how many days you're going to spend in Paris, if its a short visit you should stay in 1–6 arrondissments so that you don't lose much of your precious time getting back and forth to the center.

For a first timer 3rd & 4th (Le Marais) would be good.

8th arrondissement of Paris, which has Avenue des Champs-Élysées is an outstanding area to live in Paris if you can afford. It has many high end hotels, restaurants and bars. This area never sleeps.

Montmartre, 18th arr. is beautiful, it is situated on a hill and provides great views, Many street painters and the famous sacre couer church can be seen here. It is relatively less expensive but has a bad reputation among tourists. I lived here once, experienced nothing bad but still it is best avoided. If you decide to book your accommodation here, do your homework properly. Never book here if you're on a short visit.

If I have confused you by suggesting too many areas you can always stay at 7 arrondissment, because….Eiffel tower.

Let’s talk about public transportation.

Paris’s public transport is awesome. With options like metro, buses, trams and RER(rail), you will never have to walk or take taxis.

Metro is the best and most useful among all. Metro stations are generally located 500 meters away from each other. There are 16 metro lines.

One metro ticket costs around 2 euros, and it can be used for 90 minutes after the first use.

If you want to save some money on transport you can buy Paris transport pass. It is best for tourists staying from 1 day to a week. With this pass you can take any mode of transportation, which includes Metro, Bus, Tram and RER.

In zones 1 to 3 : travels in Paris and the close suburbs

In zones 1 to 5 : travels in Paris, the close suburbs & until Orly/CDG airports, Disneyland and Versailles

You can buy it at any metro station or here online, Paris Visite Pass - Transport ticket - Paris Tourist Office it is called Paris visite pass.

I am not sure but I have read that a monthly transport pass has been introduced recently, it costs 70 euros. Paris introduces new monthly transport pass fixed at €70

Helpful french phrases

Hello-Bonjour, overuse this word. Even if you don’t know french at all, start your conversation with this.

Do you speak English? - Parlez-vous anglais?

Yes- Oui

No - Non

No thank you - Non, merci, if someone is being over friendly or following you to sell something you can use this.

I need help- j'ai besoin d'aide

Thank you - Merci, overuse this word, be thankful.

Food is delicious everywhere, eat at small restaurants and cafes. Don’t forget to visit a french bakery.

  • Beware of pickpockets in metros and tourist areas. It is better to keep wallet and mobile in front pocket rather rare. Be attentive.
  • Dress well, don’t wear tennis shoes.
  • Wear perfumes and deodorants.
  • It is not necessary to tip the waiter.
  • Don’t speak to strangers, strangers won’t speak to you.
  • Don’t trust strangers.
  • Try to blend in the crowd, don’t stand out.
  • Try not to look like a tourist, unless you’re at Eiffel tower.
  • Sit for hours in the gardens around Eiffel tower and talk to your partner/friends, take a lot of photos, just relax and don’t rush from attraction to attraction.

answers.html:
The other answers sum it all up, more or less; moreover

  1. Paris is a very safe city... but for the touristy parts (pickpockets) --beware especially in the RER from CDG!
  2. Don't behave touristy! (big expensive-looking camera on you navel...know what I mean),
  3. Explore! You want to see Notre Dame and le Louvre and... le Canal Saint Martin, la Cité des Sciences, le musée Marmottan (see What are the most interesting museums in Paris?), le Palais de la Découverte...
  4. You're staying for some time : become un habitué (a regular) in one or two cafés near your place and elsewhere: very quickly people will recognize you; you'll know you're in when the waiter gives you 'the usual' before you have to order...then you can chat...
  5. If you like your coffee the US way, order "un café américain" with a smile...
  6. Don't take answers as rebuttals; people are busy, or they don't speak English, whatever; try someone else...eventually you'll find someone who's glad to help;(see Why do Parisians have a reputation and/or a stereotype for being rude?)
  7. Yes please do dress up a bit; jeans and a plain shirt will do ; and -yes- we don't give a damn your being a Dodgers fan...
  8. Clothing: why not keep a part of your budget to buy a few things here, (beautiful hat shops if you like that)?
  9. When you enter a shop or a bus or a train, do take off your backpack please! Not everyone does it but please...
  10. If you're in for that kind of things you can find vintage clothes and shoes at reasonable prices (see Where are the best flea markets in Paris? and Where are best vintage stores in Paris?),
  11. Look for special interest shops: vintage movie posters, vinyls, photo cameras, comics, militaria... you'll find most anything!
  12. Paris is one of the first cities in the world for movie theaters per inhabitants! Many movies are in English w/ French subtitles (look for "v.o.s.t."); why not have a Humphrey Bogart or Stanley Donen festival while you're here?
  13. If you stay in a flat, shop and cook if you can: look for the open air or closed markets and get yourself good vegetables, fruits, cheeses (What are the best places to buy cheese in Paris?), meat... try wineshops: ask the salesperson, they'll help you discover new things; you can find delicious wines at 5-10 euro...
  14. Enjoy bread and pastries (see What are the best boulangeries and patisseries in Paris for each arrondissement?),
  15. You don't say why you're staying in Paris; will you have time to take a cooking (evening) class? Then you can bring back your (new?) talents to the States...
  16. If you get to know people and are invited for dinner, bring a good bottle of wine and/or a bunch of flowers.
  17. Find before leaving what you could bring from the States as possible presents over here...
  18. Also see here Yves Granger's answer to What things do I need to know if I am visiting Paris for the first time?
  19. And here Yves Granger's answer to What should I never do in Paris?

Enjoy!

answers.html:
As a French who now lives in London, I'm going to confirm some of my compatriots suggestions :

- Do not BFF the first person you met too quickly.
French tend to be a bit colder than English-speakers but if you can pass the 1st stage of friendship, it usually mean something deeper.

- Do have a croissant, a pain au chocolat (my favorite) and feel free to try as many bakery as possible (you have no idea how much I miss that...).

- Try to speak a bit of French, to show that you're willing to try.

- DO NOT insult people in English, even if many French are bad in English, they will understand those. However, feel free to do so if you don't mind your interlocutor to understand your insults :)

- No tips necessary in restaurant, café...

- Careful with the pickpockets in the Métro (tube, underground, subway... you name it), especially around touristy places (on Line 1, also called Ligne 1, the yellow one).
The less touristy you look, the safer you are.

- Take a day to walk from the cathedral of Notre-Dame to the Arc-de-Triomphe.

- Go to La Défense (the business district) on a sunny Sunday.


- French people can be rude. As a French, even I, think we are (especially Parisians...).

- "Putain" can mean an infinity of things depending on the situation and the tone. Even though it literally means "whore", it can be good or bad.

- Paris is great but IT IS NOT the all French-experience!
Go to Reims (45min of TGV from Paris), Rennes, Lille, Lyon, Bordeaux, Strasbourg... all those cities are way more friendly than Paris on many aspects (and a lot smaller).

There are many other stuff that might be worth mentioned but nothing else come to my mind at the moment.

Have fun in Paris!
answers.content: As a French who now lives in London, I'm going to confirm some of my compatriots suggestions : - Do not BFF the first person you met too quickly.French tend to be a bit colder than English-speakers but if you can pass the 1st stage of friendship, it usually mean something deeper. - Do have a croissant, a pain au chocolat (my favorite) and feel free to try as many bakery as possible (you have no idea how much I miss that...). - Try to speak a bit of French, to show that you're willing to try. - DO NOT insult people in English, even if many French are bad in English, they will understand those. However, feel free to do so if you don't mind your interlocutor to understand your insults :) - No tips necessary in restaurant, café... - Careful with the pickpockets in the Métro (tube, underground, subway... you name it), especially around touristy places (on Line 1, also called Ligne 1, the yellow one).The less touristy you look, the safer you are. - Take a day to walk from the cathedral of Notre-Dame to the Arc-de-Triomphe. - Go to La Défense (the business district) on a sunny Sunday.- French people can be rude. As a French, even I, think we are (especially Parisians...). - "Putain" can mean an infinity of things depending on the situation and the tone. Even though it literally means "whore", it can be good or bad. - Paris is great but IT IS NOT the all French-experience!Go to Reims (45min of TGV from Paris), Rennes, Lille, Lyon, Bordeaux, Strasbourg... all those cities are way more friendly than Paris on many aspects (and a lot smaller). There are many other stuff that might be worth mentioned but nothing else come to my mind at the moment. Have fun in Paris!

propositions.content: Take a day to walk from the cathedral of Notre-Dame to the Arc-de-Triomphe.
Go to La Défense (the business district) on a sunny Sunday.
French tend to be a bit colder than English-speakers but if you can pass the 1st stage of friendship, it usually mean something deeper.
Do have a croissant, a pain au chocolat (my favorite) and feel free to try as many bakery as possible
Try to speak a bit of French, to show that you're willing to try
DO NOT insult people in English
Careful with the pickpockets in the Métro

answers.html:
Well, I'm going to try to help you out a little bit (I'm French…).

  1. Don't try to rush towards the very touristic places. As in many cities, what matters most is to feel the atmosphere of Paris. Nobody cares that you went to the Louvre or the Eiffel Tower.
  2. Museum: go to the "Centre Georges Pompidou" and the "Musée de l'Orangerie" (not matter what Lonely Planet says). If you have time, the "musée Dali", "le musée d'Orsay", and "La Pinacothèque" (often very busy) are nice. I don't even think you should go to the Louvre (it's really boring). Just wander around, the area is very nice.
  3. Current exhibitions: http://en.parisinfo.com/shows-exhibitions-paris/
  4. Language: if you can't speak French… you can't speak French, and it does not matter. Just know that most French people don't speak English properly, be patient.
  5. French people are rude.
  6. Restaurant: the tip in France has NOTHING to do with the tip in the US or Canada. Why? Because the service is included in the price in France (and all prices include VAT). If you are happy with the service, then leave one or two euros. If that is a fancy restaurant, maybe 5 or 10, but not 15% of the bill! The fact that the tip is already included often explains why the waiter won't be as nice with as he/she would have been in the US.
  7. Try not to ask American coffees and taste "un café" or "un allongé" ("café" with a more water, but still really different from a filter coffee you might get in the US). In case you would not feel well, there are more and more Starbucks in Paris :).
  8. Go to a bakery, it will be a new world for you.
  9. The metro is well developed, but avoid it around 9/10 in the morning and 5/6 in the afternoon, it will be really crowded. Since you have two months you can do a lot walking, that will allow you to feel the atmosphere of the city.


I could say a lot more but it is endless. Feel free to contact me if you have questions (I can give you some advice during your stay!).

answers.html:
The first Parisian I met in Paris told me: "Don't smile too much. It will get you in trouble!"

I disagree that Parisians are rude. They're just a little high maintenance ;)

Wear lots of neutral colors, and try a little French, even if it's just s'il vous plaît (please) and merci (thanks). It's the only French you really need!

Soak up the restaurants and museums in June and July. Lots of things will be unexpectedly closed in August. On Sundays, head to le Marais (4th arrondisement) when everything else in Paris is closed.

Take trips outside Paris if you can. Head north to Étretat, west to Mont Saint-Michel, east to Reims, and keep going south south south...

Enjoy the café culture. Since you're there June-August, a picnic is a must! Drink lots of wine, eat lots of bread and cheese. Clichéd but true! David Lebovitz has a great list of boulangeries you should visit:

http://www.travelandleisure.com/articles/paris-best-croissants.html


Go to the outdoor markets: flowers, antiques, groceries... Take the Métro everywhere. It's the most Parisian thing any visitor can do. Take Ligne 6 for no reason except to see Parisian rooftops and the Eiffel Tower en route - Surprise!


Bon voyage!
@MlleTravelista

answers.html:
If you want to take home a real piece of Paris, you won’t find it in a souvenir shop that sells tchotchkes from China. And honestly, do you really need another refrigerator magnet? Get serious about your Paris love and get off the Ile de la Cité. Shop where the Parisians shop, where you’ll have the time of your life doing it: local grocery stores, pharmacies, and the pharmacy on steroids: la parapharmacie.

What kind of souvenirs will you find in these stores? The best kind; the kind that allows you to experience Paris long after the vacation high has worn off—stuff you can savor and slather on. Not high-end products, but the everyday Parisian staples that to us are exotic and exciting. Here, a few of my favorite finds for under 20€—most under 10€!—plus, a shopping guide for where to find them.

Lotions, Potions and Soaps—Oh My!

Nothing says Paris like beauty products—the variety, the fragrances—and all in gorgeous packaging that really snazzes up the WC. The best part about French products? You can find quality at bargain prices—way cheaper in some cases than that 30€ Paris-themed sweatshirt.

Pharmacies & parapharmacies
There is a pharmacie on nearly every block in Paris (look for the green cross), and most are owned and operated by the pharmacist who can advise you in depth on every product in the shop, not only the medicines. But don’t walk into one and just start handling the products. Faux pas. This ain’t CVS, honey, this is the pharmacist’s domain. You must first see him or her (the one in the white lab coat) and explain your needs: “I’m looking for a body cream that’s light but effective.” Or, “What is the difference between this Vichy cleanser and the one by La Roche-Posay?” Truly, the pharmacist will explain these products as if they were your Xanax prescription. It’s a great way to learn about all the magical lotions and potions in store. Don’t speak French? No problem, there are pharmacies for you in districts like the Marais and Saint-Germain-des-Prés.

If you prefer to explore the products for yourself, or are too timid to speak with a pharmacist, head for a place where you are free to fondle—the parapharmacie, or any store with health and beauty aids, like Monoprix. Both of these have a larger selection than most pharmacies, and will offer inexpensive mass brands to boot. If you love HBA and love to shop, you will have the time of your life in these places.

NOTE: Always test products before using, particularly around the eye.

A FEW OF LISA’S PHARMACY FAVES

La Roche-Posay Lipikar Surgras Douche-Crème Concentrée and Lipikar Lait: All products from La Roche-Posay are top notch and dermatologist-tested, and the Lipikar line is no exception. The concentrated shower cream cleanses without soap and leaves your skin silky smooth without a residue. I love the body milk, or “lait”—super rich and luxurious. Under 15€ each, and often sold as a buy-one-get-one-half-price offer

Mixa Intensif Crème Mains Réparatrice: This little tube packs a punch for dry hands and elbows, especially rough wintertime skin. It moisturizes deeply but doesn’t leave your hands slippery. Fits in your purse, ladies, and has a subtle rose scent. A great gift. Under 4€

Christian Lenart Eau Aromatisé: Sold for over 70 years, these products are 98% natural, alcohol- and paraben-free. These lovely scented waters come in rose, cornflower, orange flower, jasmine and more, and are packaged in a cobalt blue glass bottle with a chic Art Nouveau label. Looks great on the bathroom shelf. Under 5€. A steal

Le Petit Marseillais: What’s a better souvenir or gift than French soap? This brand is a longtime staple in France, like Dove or Ivory in the States, and a staple in my shower in Paris. Delicious options like chevrefeuille (honeysuckle), sweet almond oil, orange flower, and my favorite, a pure milk soap that has a light, clean scent. Makes lots of thick, creamy suds. Under 2€ for a giant bar

Monsavon Au Lait: Well, technically, this soap is from Belgium (made since 1925!). I love the soft, spicy scent, subtle and not overwhelming. The simple blue and white wrapper speaks to another time. Under 1€ per bar. Buy a value pack and hand them out to your colleagues

Ushuaïa Shower Gels: This brand has many other products as well, but the shower gels fascinate me the most. I’ve never seen so many types and scents: toning, reinvigorating, hydrating—it never ends. They seem so exotic and indulgent, yet are dirt cheap. The Polynésie and Hammam lines are my favorite with choices like Baume de Douche Apaisant (soothing shower balm with vanilla and jojoba butter) and Lait de Douche Détoxifiant (detoxifying shower milk with green tea and mint). Under 3€ for 250 ml

Ricqlès Mint Extract: Comes in a sweet glass bottle with a black-and-white, Victorian label. Freshens breath while it classes up your medicine cabinet. Under 7€

Toothpaste and beyond: I confess I am obsessed with French toothpaste. Something you use everyday and probably rarely change, but isn’t this a wonderful opportunity? Every time you brush, you’ll think of Paris. They’re also playful gifts, a window on everyday Parisian life. Some of my favorites:Botot with it’s retro packaging and mild wintergreen flavor; Denblan, the designer toothpaste; Fluorcaril; Vademecum; the quirky Email Diamant (Diamond Enamel), made since 1893. The package has a drawing of the Barber of Seville because the creator’s sons were opera singers. See what I mean? Quirky. Most under 4€

_______________________________________________________________________

Memories You Can Eat

It doesn’t cost much to bring home the taste of Paris. As long as you have room in your checked luggage and can accommodate the extra weight, you can bring home most things, even canned goods. Note: You’ll want to bring extra Ziploc bags and a few squares of bubble wrap to safely pack items and make them leak-proof.

Grocery stores
I’ve already written about the glories of Paris grocery stores, how even the basic foodstuffs are gourmet to a non-native. These places are a treasure trove of gift ideas and edible souvenirs. There are several chains in Paris—Monoprix, Franprix, Carrefour City—but also many small convenience stores and traiteurs you can, and should, visit. NOTE: Be sure to check with your country’s customs guidelines to be sure what food items are permitted.

LISA’S TREASURED TREATS

There’s no reason why you shouldn’t bring home a can of foie gras, chestnut preserves or organic speculoos-speckled dark chocolate in lieu of key chains, tee shirts and snow globes. Here are some other ideas:

Spices and salts: Usually quite lightweight (luggage!) and often in decorative tins(Terre Exotique) or glass jars (Albert Ménès), you can’t go wrong with spices. Truffled salts and French sea salts are another great idea and many are packaged beautifully, like Le Saunier de Camargue Fleur de Sel with its cork lid. Your friends will be thrilled to receive these as gifts, and you’ll love sprinkling a little Paris on your favorite foods back home. What could be better? Most under 15€; many under 5€

Mustards and mayos: No one does these better than the French in my opinion, especially mayonnaise, which is so much eggier than ours. I like the mayos that come in a tube, like Lesieur and Bénédicta. Mustards, or moutards, abound—from the basic yellow stuff to the gourmet, infused versions. My favorites: mustard with cognac from Albert Ménès, and mustard with walnut from Clovis (only 1.65€!), but you’ll find more flavors and brands than you can carry home. Most under 4€

Chocolates: Yes, you can spend a lot of money on gourmet chocolate in Paris, but you don’t have to. At Monoprix there are about a zillion choices including organic (or “bio”) and artisanal styles. Way better than a ‘fridge magnet, am I right? Under 10€; most under 5€

Nothing says Paris like beauty products—the variety, the fragrances—and all in gorgeous packaging that really snazzes up the WC.

Pharmacies & parapharmacies
There is a pharmacie on nearly every block in Paris (look for the green cross), and most are owned and operated by the pharmacist who can advise you in depth on every product in the shop, not only the medicines.
Don’t speak French? No problem, there are pharmacies for you in districts like the Marais and Saint-Germain-des-Prés.

If you prefer to explore the products for yourself, or are too timid to speak with a pharmacist, head for a place where you are free to fondle—the parapharmacie, or any store with health and beauty aids, like Monoprix.
La Roche-Posay Lipikar Surgras Douche-Crème Concentrée and Lipikar Lait: All products from La Roche-Posay are top notch and dermatologist-tested, and the Lipikar line is no exception.
Mixa Intensif Crème Mains Réparatrice: This little tube packs a punch for dry hands and elbows, especially rough wintertime skin.
Christian Lenart Eau Aromatisé: Sold for over 70 years, these products are 98% natural, alcohol- and paraben-free.
Le Petit Marseillais: What’s a better souvenir or gift than French soap? This brand is a longtime staple in France, like Dove or Ivory in the States, and a staple in my shower in Paris.
Monsavon Au Lait: Well, technically, this soap is from Belgium (made since 1925!). I love the soft, spicy scent, subtle and not overwhelming.
Ushuaïa Shower Gels: This brand has many other products as well, but the shower gels fascinate me the most. I’ve never seen so many types and scents: toning, reinvigorating, hydrating—it never ends.
Ricqlès Mint Extract: Comes in a sweet glass bottle with a black-and-white, Victorian label. Freshens breath while it classes up your medicine cabinet. Under 7€

Toothpaste and beyond: I confess I am obsessed with French toothpaste. Something you use everyday and probably rarely change, but isn’t this a wonderful opportunity? Every time you brush, you’ll think of Paris.

They’re also playful gifts, a window on everyday Parisian life. Some of my favorites:Botot with it’s retro packaging and mild wintergreen flavor; Denblan, the designer toothpaste; Fluorcaril; Vademecum; the quirky Email Diamant (Diamond Enamel), made since 1893.

Grocery stores
I’ve already written about the glories of Paris grocery stores, how even the basic foodstuffs are gourmet to a non-native. These places are a treasure trove of gift ideas and edible souvenirs. There are several chains in Paris—Monoprix, Franprix, Carrefour City—but also many small convenience stores and traiteurs you can, and should, visit. NOTE: Be sure to check with your country’s customs guidelines to be sure what food items are permitted.

Spices and salts: Usually quite lightweight (luggage!) and often in decorative tins(Terre Exotique) or glass jars (Albert Ménès), you can’t go wrong with spices. Truffled salts and French sea salts are another great idea and many are packaged beautifully, like Le Saunier de Camargue Fleur de Sel with its cork lid.
Mustards and mayos: No one does these better than the French in my opinion, especially mayonnaise, which is so much eggier than ours. I like the mayos that come in a tube, like Lesieur and Bénédicta.
Chocolates: Yes, you can spend a lot of money on gourmet chocolate in Paris, but you don’t have to. At Monoprix there are about a zillion choices including organic (or “bio”) and artisanal styles.

For Breakfast; Hot Chocolate, Cafe au lait or a Capuccino with a fresh brioche or a croissant with butter and jam

Lunch Simple is a ham and cheese sandwich on a crusty roll. Or go to a local market and get whatever street food they are offering. For a more formal lunch try a little bistro and get the menu of the day. Best deal and freshly made.

Dinner start with a glass of some sparkling wine with a side of cheese flutes(Feuilletees au fromage) then go to a neighborhood restaurant away from the tourist zones. Start with a country pate served with pickles and sharp mustard, then fresh sole or turbot sauteed with butter wine and lemon and finish with profiteroles drowned in decadent chocolate sauce.

answers.html:
Paris being the world’s most touristic destination also known for it’s European weather, Parisian culture, Fashion and last but not the least it’s FOOD.

Paris has influenced the world’s gastronomy, cooks and gourments. Food is the greatest attractions of the city - it’s food is also known as piece of medivial food. Before listing down the foods that we should try in Paris let’s understand the food history first. During the 16th century the cheese, cured meats, baguettes, costed ducks, fine wine and croissants were time-tested and advanced cooking techniques were implied to combine classic flavors and ingredients in magical ways. French culture generally doesn’t reply on preservatives and artificial flavorings. The french cheese doesn’t go with the famous way of pasturatisation. French people make emphasis very much on the 4 elements of best cooking such as the flavour, creativity, color and smell.

French foods are generally called as Techno-Emotional Foods. I have listed down my favourite food items through personal experience.

Feel like a local while trying out these listed foods

1. Baguettes

Baguette - Crunchy on the outside and airy on the inside. This makes it a winning combination, referring from my personal experience the listed places are the best to satisfy your baguette cravings

Maison - Julien located at 13, Rue Pierre Demours 75017

Boulangerie Marytrs - 70 Rue des Martyrs 75009

If you are on budget then baguette stalls near the station of Chatelet will curve down your cravings.

2. Croissants

Parisians are famous for having croissants for their breakfast with a shot of expresso coffee. Here is a few list of best croissant places in Paris

Maison Pichard - They are best known to be in this business for 20 years and have been awarded the best croissant in Paris.

Address: 88 Rue Cambronne, Paris

Café Pouchkine - I have had the best experiences in this café located in the Place de la Madeleine. The best croissant that you can try here is Croissant a la Vanille.

Address: 16, Place de la Madeleine, Paris

3. Macroons

Even though the history of Macroons was not clear but they say it came from Italy through the Macroon sisters of Italy. Someone born with a sweet tooth can satisfy their sweet cravings at the listed places in Paris

Ladurée - The Pierre Herme started making macaroons in the 1900’s and is one of the bests in the whole country. You can just sit relax and have a macaroon here. They have more than 10+ flavours in macaroons.

Address: 16, Rue Royale Paris

For more budget friendly options you can consider 18, Place de la bastille offers the best macaroons without digging a whole in your pocket.

4. Cheese

We can get access to the best cheese in Paris through various super markets and different boulangeries but according to my experience I would recommend the below listed boulongeries

Chez Virginie - This cheese shop was started in 1900’s. They offer various forms of cheese for you to taste.

Address: 54 Rue Damrémont, 75018 Paris

La Ferme Sait Hubert - It’s the best shop for picnic and cocktail party.

Address: 36 Rue de Rochechouart 75009

For budget friendly cheese experience we can get access into the supermarkets in Paris such as the carrefour, Monoprix and etc...

5. Oyster

Oysters are very sweet and full of fats. You can get hands on experience in the following places

Pleine Mer - It offers the best seafood from fresh seawaters you can eat dozens of oysters from th range of only 10-19 euros.

Address: 22, Rue de Chabrol 75010

Clamato - It’s a super chic seafood restaurant for hipsters and seafood lovers and their oysters are to die for. We can have the best dine in experience in budget around 16-18 euros.

Address: 80 Rue de Charonne, 75011

Hope you like all the suggestions and have the best experience in Paris!!

answers.html:
If you are in Paris, there are always many places and activities to add to your list. During our visit to Paris using the Pickyourtrail Europe package, we were determined to try out as many local dishes as we could. From our experience, here are the top dishes that you should try when you are in Paris:

Pastries are famous in Paris and every Parisian bakery will have a huge range of delectable sweet pastries that you should try out.

The local cheese is truly to-die-for. Most of your dishes will be dusted with cheese.

The macarons are yummy here and if you love them, do not miss out on them

The croissants and baguettes are the most famous in Paris and were delicious.

Another thing to remember is to complement your dishes with a glass of wine. Always ask your waiter for their recommendation because the perfect wine pairing can elevate your dish.

answers.html:
Depends on what you want to buy.

If you’re looking for pricey, fashionable stuff, the rue St. Honore’ and the Place des Victoires. If you REALLY want to go upscale, the Place Vendome.

If you’re looking for fashionable but not necessarily high-priced clothes, gifts, jewelry etc., the Marais (which is a great place to stroll in general).

If you’re looking for books, the Boulevard St. Michel and neighboring areas.

If you want electronics, records, etc. go to the Forum des Halles which is pretty much a shopping mall in an inverted underground pyramid.

Innumerable markets for food if you’re looking for that. Ethnic food over at the marche’ d’Aligre, organic stuff on the Boulevard Raspail, simple fare like cheeses, breads, olives, on the rue Mouffetard or the market street the rue Montorgeuil.

If you want to buy art and old collectibles (books, etc.), the rue de Seine. For upscale antiquing, the Marche’ aux Puces at Clignancourt.

answers.html:
I’ll add a few more to the already great answers:

  • Don’t confuse Paris and Disneyland. The latter is designed to provide you an “optimal guest experience”; the former is a functioning major world capital where people are trying to go to work and live their life. Not everything in Paris has been designed to provide an “optimal guest experience”.
  • If you can avoid it, don’t go to Gare du Nord, Châtelet, or Montparnasse stations (among others) between 8:00 and 9:30 AM and especially don’t go with all your luggage expecting to easily get on a train… (And while I’m on the topic, if you have never or rarely ridden mass transit, please take some time to familiarize yourself with the concept before you arrive. The bus, métro, tramway, RER website is a great start and it’s even available in other languages.)
  • Don’t stand on the métro or RER platform in front of the doors expecting to rush in immediately; please let those already in the train get off first.
  • When you go into a shop or restaurant, in addition to “bonjour” when you arrive, also say “merci, au revoir” when you leave. If you need an employee’s attention, start with “excusez-moi de vous déranger” or at least “s’il vous plaît”.
  • No matter what you may have learned or seen in movies, waiters are not called “garçon” or summoned by snapping one’s fingers. If you need their attention, try waving your hand and saying “s’il vous plaît” repeatedly. Also, even though “service” is already included in the price, an additional token tip (like 20 centimes for a simple cup of coffee or 1 euro per person for a meal) is still expected/appreciated.
  • If you are coming from outside the Euro zone, get used quickly to the currency. Fumbling with the coins to figure each one out when you are at the head of the line is considered quite rude.

ETA: one more point about restaurants: many restaurants are only open from 12 - 14 (2 PM) and 19 - 23 (7 - 11 PM). Don’t be surprised!

answers.html:
You will be expected to want to eat bread, or pastries, at every meal. At breakfast it's generally clear that it goes on your tray or your tray sized paper table mat. At other times you generally don't butter it, but take a slice or break a piece off at a time, and keep it alongside your plate. Just keep your eyes open and do what your fellow diners do.

Plates and cutlery too can be a nightmare. Watch others to see if you will be keeping the same plate and cutlery for the next course. Leave cutlery alongside your plate, neatly together is often the best recourse.

People do not generally eat in the street, the French need to sit to eat. Smokers stand around.

Children are welcome, as are dogs, in many places but both are expected to behave. Paris is trying to get people to clean up mess from their dogs, but even so look where you put your feet.

There always used to be a problem finding decent public toilets. Instead you need to order a drink at a cafe, then use theirs. Do not just go in and use them. Alternatively remember to “go” just before you leave your accommodation.

Do not “flash the cash”, dress neatly but not ostentatiously. Paris has its fair share of street thieves but Parisians are not robbed excessively. If you are driving a car, remember to pull down the flap that can cover the radio when you park it. Also you won't see many phones on tables, or bags hung on the back of chairs.

Children are welcome, as are dogs, in many places but both are expected to behave. Paris is trying to get people to clean up mess from their dogs, but even so look where you put your feet.

There always used to be a problem finding decent public toilets. Instead you need to order a drink at a cafe, then use theirs. Do not just go in and use them. Alternatively remember to “go” just before you leave your accommodation.

Do not “flash the cash”, dress neatly but not ostentatiously. Paris has its fair share of street thieves but Parisians are not robbed excessively. If you are driving a car, remember to pull down the flap that can cover the radio when you park it. Also you won't see many phones on tables, or bags hung on the back of chairs.

propositions.content: People do not generally eat in the street, the French need to sit to eat.

answers.html:
• Do remember that France can be quite bureaucratic at times: Standing in line or waiting to for your turn can be frustrating. Take the opportunity to focus on things that are new and interesting, and relax.
  • Do learn a few French phrases: Bonjour (pronounced BON-zhoor) means hello or good morning; a bientot (pronounced a bee-yen-TOE) means see you soon; au revoir (pronounced OH-vwahr) means goodbye; and merci (pronounced mare-SEE) means thank you. Greet shopkeepers or strangers with "bonjour, Monsieur" or "bonjour, Madame". Also remember that French people are not generally on a first-name basis with strangers, especially in business or other formal situations.
  • Do take some time to just walk around the city without any specific destination. Paris is a very walkable city and you may be pleasantly surprised by what you run into.
  • Don't change metro lines at the Chatelet or Montparnasse stations (if you can avoid it), as you may be in for a very long walk.
  • Do talk quietly on the phone and in person. Parisians are very private and enjoy quiet in public places such as trains, buses, parks and restaurants. If you need to make a call, go outside or into designated areas or hallways to avoid disturbing others with your conversation.
  • Do use Line 6 of the metro, which partly runs above ground. You will enjoy a great view of the Eiffel Tower from the bridge Bir-Hakeim (close to metro station Bir-Hakeim). Do enjoy the aerial views of Paris, not just from the Eiffel Tower, but also from the Tour Montparnasse (686 ft/209 m), the rooftop bar at Hotel Concorde La Fayette (449 ft/137m), the Grande Arche de la Defense (361 ft/110 m), Sacre Coeur (272 ft/83 m), Arc de Triomphe (164 ft/50 m) and from the towers of Notre Dame (226 ft/69 m). Other great viewing spots include the Pantheon, the roof terraces of the Galeries Lafayette and Printemps stores, the upper floor of the Centre Pompidou and the roof terrace of the restaurant in the Institut du Monde Arabe.
  • Do avoid breakfast at cheaper hotels; it is usually overpriced and of poor quality. Instead, opt for a fluffy, fresh croissant and a cafe au lait in a nearby cafe or, better yet, from a boulangerie (bakery).
  • Do remember when dining in France that the "carte" is the menu, while "menu" means a fixed-price meal consisting of a starter, main course and/or dessert. An "entree" is the appetizer or starter, not the main course (which is called the "plat"), and the cheese course comes before dessert. Try out new food on French menus by asking for the chef's plat du jour.
  • Don't smoke in bars, restaurants, discos, metro stations and most indoor public places. It is illegal to do so throughout France, and you may be fined.

answers.html:
Brace yourself for what I'm about to explain you will save you a lot of time.

If you choose to do some shopping in Paris, make sure you'll be there during sales. France has 2 national sales time: Winter and Summer. Usually they fall in later January, right after Christmas when you're already broke, and right in the middle of summer to remind you how your existence is miserable when all your friends are enjoying vacations in Brittany and eating fresh oysters in their marinière, The Riviera coast where their granny bought a "small house by the beach in the 70's" or abroad.

Of course, you'll find stuff from winter in winter and summer in summer because it's so much fun to buy outdated tops in late summer while you're looking for a jacket for the cold weather. It's called French humour. So think about not showing up right at the beginning of sales but a week after when the sales persons decide to cut us some slack with hanging in the store the raggedy collection from 5 seasons ago and preciously kept in the back room.

If you decide to shop in the center of Paris here are the street while you'll have the most of brands:

  • Rue Étienne Marcel (and surroundings). You'll find there all the girly girl brand but also the Paris chic ones: Replay, Zadig et Voltaire, Comptoir des cotonniers, Agnes B., jonak, Ash, Barbara Bui, Guess, C.O.S. And my favorite glasses store (but don't tell anyone): Marc Lebihan. Spoiler: if you feel like you're in the same mood than Beyonce in her video clip "[Girls] who run the World", you can try, I mean Tuuuhryy, to go to Chatelet, The underground mall. There, you will find la crème de la crème of what a mall in the inner city can be but be aware that once you've spend more that 2 hours in there, you'll feel like Kimmy Schmidt getting out of her bunker: desperately genuine and embarrassingly confident with your purchases.
  • Rue de la Chaussée d'Antin ( and surroundings): you will find a lot of shoes and lingerie stores in this street right behind of Les Galleries Lafayette and le Printemps. It has this strange flavor of fashion empowering success, like describe famous Emile Zola's novel Au Bonheur des Dames (a sort of inspiration for The British TV show Selfridge): you will find luxury brands spreading from Rue Tronchet, Boulevard des Capucines until the Boulevard Haussmann where the famous French department stores are located. But Rue de la Chaussée d'Antin gathers cute brands that are still affordable.
  • Rue de Rennes: The left bank street for a cool shopping, right by the boulevard Saint Germain until the train Station Montparnasse. With No surprise, you'll find many mainstream brands like Zara and H&M but you will also find some quirky clothes and bags stores promoting somehow made in France.
  • Rue de Passy. Now we're talking bougie shopping, I know, I know, it's not exactly everyone’s budget but these streets are full of cute shoes stores - yes I love shoes, use to own more than 70 pairs back in the days- and even bargain stores where you might find good deal of fashion brands.

answers.html:
There are too many to pick the best, but I used to walk to work through the Palais Royal daily.

Here is a surprising one that I just discovered a couple of days ago. Seems relatively unknown as it is not visible from ground level. Only saw locals there, doesn’t seem to attract the local drunks. Surprisingly large, with tennis courts too. The Jardin Atlantique is on the roof of the busy Gare Montparnasse, a huge station. A couple of photos I took during my visit, so it’s still in winter mode.

You will find a lot of nice and quiet squares with bunches and flowers if you just walk in the streets.

Also from Porte de la Muette, you can access to a beautiful lake in the Bois de Boulogne. There are a lot of parisians walking/jogging around with their kids. And you still can see the eiffel tower from there.

answers.html:
Alongside world famous attractions,cuisines and romantic ventures in Paris,there are also some fine parks and garden situated within the city for not just children but also for adults.

  • Jardin du Luxembourg-Among the many parks and gardens of Paris,the Luxembourg Garden is certainly one of the favourite green places of Parisians,students and tourists.Multitude of playground,statues and the famous Guignol puppet show.
  • Jardin des Plantes-More than just a public garden, the Jardin des Plantes is the main botanical garden in France. Situated in the 5th arrondissement,the garden features a beautiful rose garden,a small zoo and historic glasshouses.
  • Champ de Mars-The green esplanade(open area) of the Champ de Mars spreads between the classical façade of the École Militaire and the famous Eiffel Tower.Anywhere that you sit in this park you can have the view of the Eiffel Tower so grand that you will not forget it ever.
  • Parc des Buttes Chaumont-This park consists of a grotto,a waterfall and a Roman Temple on the top of the promontory known as the Temple de la Sibylle,which is a miniature version of Temple of Vesta,Tivoli in Italy.
  • Cimetière du Père Lachaise .-Against all odds,the Père Lachaise Cemetery in the east of Paris is one of the favourite green place to Parisians and tourists alike.The largest cemetery of the City of Paris, Père Lachaise is also the first garden cemetery and greatly differs from other similar places such as the Montmartre or Montparnasse cemeteries.Along the promenade,visitors can discover the graves of many celebrities.
  • Lac Daumesnil-The artificial Daumesnil Lake is set in a beautiful English garden and includes two islands on which stand a Temple of love and a Swiss Chalet.

answers.html:
Some people already sent you nice spots but I’d say:

Museums: Musée Cognac-Jay - below - with its nice collections of 18th century items or the Musée des Beaux-Arts (located in the Petit Palais) with its lovely painting collections from Medieval Orthodox Icons to Early 20th century art. Both free.

Parks: Buttes-Chaumont with its hilly curves and stunning views. As well as the Parc de Belleville with its breathtaking panorama on Paris. Parc de Bercy is lovely with its abundants flowerbeds (below) and ponds.

Streets: Some streets and neighborhoods deserve a little walk. I personally love Rue Mouffetard - below - with its many bars and groceries. Rue Saint-Anne is a Japanese-Korean street of Paris, it’s very nice of all the Far East cuisine enthusiasts. In general the Marais (gay/jewish districts) and the Quartier Latin (Sorbonne/Panthéon district) both deserve a walk.

Riverside picnics: I personally love picnics so if you want to grab some food and a bottle of wine go to Square du Vert-Galant on Île de la Cité or Place d’Aragon on Île Saint-Louis. If you prefer a more alternative and less crowded location, Bassin de la Villette offers a perfect urban spot for a picnic (below), particularly at night because there is no tree along the water so the sun can be harsh in summer.

I hope my list with help you to shape a nice and unexpected journey in Paris ;)
